'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

div.p: THE Love-ſick Court OR THE Ambitious Politique.

p.hi: Nil mea, ceu mos eſt, commendes carmina curo

div.p: LONDON, Printed by J. T. for A. C. and are to be ſold by Henry Broom, at the Gun in Ivie-lane, 1658.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: A little wit, leſſe learning, no Poetry
This Play-maker dares boaſt: Tis his modeſty.
For though his labours have not found leaſt grace,
It puffs not him up or in minde or face,
Which makes him rather in the Art diſclame
Bold Licenſe, then to arrogate a Name;
Yet to the wit, the ſcholler, and the Poet,
Such as the Play is, we muſt dare to ſhow it
Our judgements to but too: And without fear
Of giving leaſt offence to any ear.
If you finde pleaſure in't, we boaſting none,
Nor you nor we loſe by' expectation.
Sometimes at poor mens boards the curious finde
'Mongſt homely fare, ſome unexpected diſh,
Which at great Tables they may want and wiſh:
If in this ſlight Collation you will binde
Ʋs to believe you' have pleasd your pallats here,
Pray bring your friends w'you next, you know your cheor.

list.item: Philargus, the Prince, ſuppoſed Son of the late ſlain General.
Philocles, A young Nobleman ſon of the late General, and twin with Philargus.
Euphalus, A Gentleman belonging to the King.
Geron, A curious Coxcomb and a Schollar.
Matho, A villain, ſervant to Stratocles.
Terſulus, A Taylor, ſervant to Philargus.
Ʋarillus, A Barbar, ſervant to Philocles.

sp.speaker: _DIſ.
sp.l: Good morrow my good Lord. How fares the King?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: More ſick in mind then body, by th'opinion,
(Not onely of the skilful Doctors, but) of all
That come about him.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I that have not ſeen him
Since he was ſick, can gueſs, then at the cauſe
Of his diſtemper. He is ſick o'th'ſubject;
Th'unquiet Commons fill his head and breaſt
With their impertinent diſcontents and ſtrife.
The peace that his good care has kept'hem in
For many years, ſtill feeding them with plenty,
Hath, like ore pampered ſteeds that throw their Maſters,
Set them at war with him. O miſery of kings!
His vertue breeds their vices; and his goodneſs
Pulls all their ills upon him. He has been
Too long too lenetive: A thouſand heads
(Or ſay a hundred, or but ten) cut off
Of the moſt groſs ones, the prime, leading heads
Of theirs a moneth ſince, had preſerv'd him better
Then all his doctors pills can purge him now.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: You are too ſharp Diſanius. There's a means,
As milde as other of the Kings clear Acts,
In agitation now, ſhall reconcile
All to a common peace no doubt.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What's that Juſtinius?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Stay: Here comes Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I fear, in that
Ambitious pate lies the combuſtable ſtuff
Of all this late commotion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why is man
Preſcrib'd on earth to imitate the Gods,
But to come neareſt them in power and action?
That is to be a King! That onely thought
Fills this capacious breaſt. A King or nothing!

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: He's deep in meditation.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: On no good.
It is ſome divelliſh waking dream affects him.
I'le put him out—And as I was about
To ſay my Lord.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What? when Diſanius?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: About a moneth ſince,
It ſtick ſtill in my jaws. Be not ambitious,
Affect not popularity. 'Tis the moſt
Notable break-neck in a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: In whom?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I know to whom I ſpeak; would Stratocles
As well knew who he is, and what he does:
It would be better for him. Thank me not,
I wiſh it for the king and kingdoms good,
Not yours I do aſſure you, my great Lord;
Yet mine own Peer, if you forget me not.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You take your time Sir to make me your mirth.
A time may come—

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: When you may be my King,
And then up goes Diſanius. Is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes, upto Court, to be king Stratocles fool.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: The Court now priviledges thee, or I would change
A cuffe with your great Souldier-ſhip and popular great|neſs
With clowns and Citizens, and Gentry, ſprung
By their late peaceful wealth, out of their dongue.
But let'em thank our pious King, not you
That claim (as merit for your ſervice done)
Their loves and voices.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: Ceaſe my Lords this ſtrife.
The King may hear on't, whoſe perplexities
Already are too grievous. Pray be ſilent,
The king approaches.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Wee'll attend his entrance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.stage: Upon thoſe terms they are come then, Eupathus?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Four of the chief in the commotion,
Upon the ingagement of my faith, that you
Had paſt your kingly word for their return
In ſafety, I have brought to Court, who wait
Your preſent will and pleaſure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bring'em in.
Diſanius, welcome. I thought well to ſend for you
To take a Councellors part of my late cares
Into your conſideration.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I attend
Your Highneſs pleaſure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nearer good Diſanius.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do you deal in ſecret king? The Commons ſent for
To their examination, and this old
Antagoniſt of mine cal'd to confront me,
And I prepar'd by no intelligence
To fit me for th'incounter? Let'em come.
I muſt not be deny'd to ſtand as fair
In competition for the Crown as any man
The King himſelf elects for his ſucceſſor;
The people are mine own thro' all his parts:
He may command their knees, but I their hearts.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stratocles, Juſtinius, Diſanius ſit.
My lords, altho'our Lawes of Theſſaly
To you, as well as to our ſelf, are known,
And all our cuſtoms, yet for orders ſake
I ſhall lay open one to you. That is, when
A king deceaſeth without iſſue male
(As I unfortunately muſt) the Commons
Are to elect their King, provided that
He be of noble blood, a ſculdier, and one
That has done publick ſervice for the Crown—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That makes for me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Or elſe the ſon of ſome
Great General ſlain in battel for his countrey
(As my Adrastus was.)

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O my brave brother!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Twenty years ſorrow for that Souldiers loſs
Has not worn out his memory.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your grace
Forgets not then Souldiers of freſher fame.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Some other time to boaſt good Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Twere good youl'd hear the king—A general,
Or a Generals ſon may be elected. There
Your Majeſty left.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Or if the ſonleſs King
Yet has a daughter, and he match her in
His life time to a husband that is noble,
He ſtands immediate heir unto the Crown
Againſt all contradiction.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Now think upon my ſervice, Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Now think upon my Nephewes, Royal Maſter,
The ſons of brave Adraſtus, who was ſlain
Twenty years ſince in fighting of your battel.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Twere good you would hear the king. The husband of
Your daughter muſt be elected. There you left, ſir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It reſts now that a ſpeedy choice be made
Of a fit husband, one that may acquire
Eudynas love, and peoples approbation,
The people, (for whoſe noiſe I muſt not reſt
Till my ſucceſſor be appointed to them)
Are wild till this election be made:
They have, in arms, made their demand, and wait
My preſent anſwer.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O here they come. Theſe be the principals 4 Ruſtiks.
The heads, the heads, forſooth they call themſelves.
Head-carpenter, head-ſmith, head-plowman, & head-ſhep|herd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Nay, pray approach; & ſeem no more abaſh'd
Here then amongſt your giddy-headed rowts,
Where every man's a King, and wage your powers
Gainſt mine in ſoul defiance. Freely ſpeak
Your grievance, and your full demand.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Tis humbly all expreſt in this petition.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.p: By all means have a care that, to any queſtion, we give the King good words to his face; He is another manner of man here then we took him for at home.

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.p: I ſweat for't. I am ſure I have ſcarce a dry thred in my leather lynings.

sp.speaker: 4. Ruſ.
sp.p: They made us heads i' the countrey: But if our head-ſhips now, with all our countrey care ſhould be hang'd up at court for diſpleaſing of this good King, for the next Kings good our necks will not be ſet right a-again in the next Kings raign I take it.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: My head itches to be at home again.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: My head itches to be at home again.

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.l: My head and heart both akes for fear. Would
I were honeſtly hang'd out o'the way to be rid on't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: There you may read my Lords what we before
Found would be their demand. Tis for a King
That muſt ſucceed me.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: And becauſe you have
Govern'd them long in peace, by which they thrive
Their wiſdom would have you intail that piece
On them for after times; and ſo they nominate
Ambitious Stratocles to be your heir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Envious Diſanius, my merit is
Their Motive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ceaſe your ſtrife.—You have ſtood, more in|clin'd
To lay your choiſe on Philocles, or Philargus
The Twin-born ſons of long ſince ſlain Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: May't pleaſe your Majeſty we are inform'd
That in their travails unto Delphos, both
Of them are dead.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: That information
Was meerly by ſuggeſtion (I dare ſpeak it)
Inſinuated by Stratocles. They both live
And are upon return.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Would we knew that.
Lord Stratocles then ſhould pardon us. Hee's a man
Gracious amongſt us. But—

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: Philargus! O—
Philargus, be he living.

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.l: I ſay Philocles.
Brave Philocles is the man.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Falſe, empty weathercocks.

sp.speaker: 4. Ruſ.
sp.l: I ſay Lord Stratocles is the man we know
And ought to honour.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: There lives yet ſome hope.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: What ſtrange confuſions this? Or whither will
You run by ſeveral wayes? Philargus one,
Another Philocles; a third cries Stratocles.
In this you ſay you'l have no king at all.
This muſt be reconcil'd, or you pull ruine
Upon your ſelves. He, whom the king is pleaſ'd
To give his daughter to muſt be your King.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: All that we crave (and that upon our knees)
Is, that the king will graciouſly be pleas'd
To make a ſpeedy choice, and give us leave
With pardon to depart, and ſignifie
His Royal pleaſure to the doubtful countreys.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell'em they ſhall expect, then, but a moneth,
In which ſhort time my daughters marriage
Shall be conſummate.

sp.speaker: All Ruſ.
sp.l: The Gods protect your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now, my Lords, the commons being at peace,
Let me prevail your private jarrs to ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Madam, the cauſe is mine; tis mine to mourn
In chief, if they be dead. They were your ſons,
Tis true, and though they were your onely comforts
Upon this earth, you but reſigne to heaven
The bleſſings that it lent you. But to me
They were a pair of equal lovers; and
By me ſo equally belov'd; and by
The king my father ſo 'bove all men reſpected
That I by either had been made a Queen,
Which title I for ever will diſclaim
If they be dead.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O my Philargus. O my Philocles!
Ye Gods I know they did not ſeek your Counſels
Nor dare to approach your altars, but with all
Due reverence and required ceremony.
And could your Delphian Oracle, when they
Were friendly competitioners for love,
Anſwer them but with death?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: The rumor, Madam,
Carries ſo little ſhew of truth, that you
Do ill to take ſo deep a ſenſe of it;
Much worſe t'expoſtulate, as if you had
An injury done you by the Gods. Have you
Been from mine infancy my governeſs,
And careful councel-giver; and muſt I
Find cauſe to chide you now? come dry theſe tears.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Where's my ſweet princeſs?
Where's my Lady governeſs?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O Garrula, welcome. I could never wiſh
Thy company more uſefully: For thou bring'ſt
Some recreation on thy countenance alwayes.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I am glad my countenance pleaſes you. It may:
For I have on it now (could you diſcern'em)
A thouſand joyes dancing within theſe wrincles
More then my feeble failing tongue can utter.
And that's a grief to me 'mong all my joyes;
The failing of the tongue, the tongue, the tongue
Is a great grief to any woman. But
To one in years, and well in years, as I am,
It is a grief indeed, more then the loſs
Of any other member.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: But I pray thee
Let not that grief deprive us of the hearing
Of, at leaſt, one of thy whole thouſand joyes.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Tis a report of joy and wonder, princeſs;
Enough to make not onely you, and you,
But King and kingdom glad, could I but utter't.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thou doſt ſpeak well enough, and enough too,
I pray thee tell it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Tis ſome faign'd ſtuffe
She hopes to palliate our ſorrowes with.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis a report, worth more then all the ſtories
That I my ſelf have told in child-bed chambers,
To reſtore ſpirit to the pallid fleſh.
And I have been a woman as good at it
(Without vain boaſt bee't ſpoke) as any ſhe
In Theſſaly, that ere durſt undertake
The office of a Midwiſe: And that the queen
Your Mother knew, when I delivered her
Of the ſweet babe (your ſelf.) She is in bliſſe
Now in Eliſium. But you, Madam Governeſſe,
Can yet remember good old Garrula,
That took into the light your twin-born ſons,
And thereby hangs a tale—

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What means this woman?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good Garrula, thy newes? thy preſent ſtory?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſuch a ſtory, that could I but utter't
With volubility of tongue!—But O
This tongue, that fails me now; for all the helps
Of Syrups, and ſweet ſippings. I ſtill go
sp.stage: She ſips oft of a bottle ather girdle.
sp.l: Provided, as you ſee, to cheriſh it.
And yet it falters with me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: We ſhall ha't
Anon I hope. Placilla, whats your news?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent Madam. And I was ambitious
To bring you the firſt taſte of it. But if
Garrula has in that prevented me,
I can with no leſſe joy relate it yet.
My brothers are return'd, and ſafe, from Delphos.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Be thou as true as th'Oracle.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Now, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Mother, tis true.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis that I would ha'told you
Had not my tongue fail'd me i'th' utterance.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thy tongue ran faſt enough, but loſt its way.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Three minutes, Madam, brings'em to your preſence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: How is it with you, Madam? Let not joy
Beget a worſe effect then did your fears.
Help, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Ods pity, what dee mean.
Madam, look up, and ſpeak up too you were beſt,
Do you know who talks to you? Speak; and ſpeak well too.
I ſhall ſpeak that will be worſe for you elſe.
Madam, you know, that I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I am well I thank you, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: O are you ſo?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I have obſerv'd that often in her language,
This chattring Midwife glanceth at the knowledge
Of ſome ſtrange hidden thing, which like as with
A Charm, ſhe keeps my Governeſs in aw with.
I gueſs it but ſome trifle: For I know
The Lady is right vertuous; yet it may
Be worth my inquiſition at fit time.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You have felt the comforts of my friendſhip Gar|rula,
And had you common charity, you'd forbear me.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I—done Madam. Be ſecure. But yet,
Though I forbear to ſpeak, I not forget.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You have not yet, Placilla, told the means
Of your rich knowledge.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Nor ſhall I need now Madam
Theſe ſhouts of joy that follow'd them to Court
Attend them to your preſence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O let us meet'em. Madam, come away.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O ye Gods, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I have a ſon there too, as dear to me
As any Mothers onely born can be,
Whoſe name's not voic'd with theirs. Yet by your favour
Great Madam Governeſs, he has diſcharg'd
The office of a Governor ore your ſons,
As well as you have over the Kings daughter.
And they have ſuck'd more of his Helycon
Then ſhe has of your doctrin: which their breeding
Together with their Travels through his care
Will teſtifie (I doubt not) to my honor,
That have brought forth a ſon of ſuch performance.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Did not I ſay, 'twas Stratocles that rais'd
sp.stage: Ent. Diſ. Jus. Phila. Philo. Eud. Thy: Pla. Geron.
sp.l: That hideous rumor of their deaths, among
His wilde idolators, in hope to gain
Election by their ignorance and rudeneſs?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: 'Twas well thoſe factious heads were wrought to come
Before the King to finde his clemencie,
And probabilily that theſe were living.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: And how they then ſhrunk in their necks from Stratocles!
It has ſo laid the flames of his ambition,
That theſe may ſafely now tread out the fire.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: Welcom again my princely Nephews, welcom.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thanks, courteous Uncle.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You interrupt me, brother.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Good woman, cry thee mercy. Mothers are ſuch things!

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Why, what things are we mothers?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O the old night-piece with her dark lanthorne by her.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You'l give us leave to take
The comforts due unto us in our age,
For which we ſuffer'd ſorrow in our youth!
Our children are our children young or old.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: So is my horſe my horſe.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You have repli'd,
As Whilome did a Councellour at Law,
Who ſaid his adverſe Advocate had pleaded
To as much purpoſe as a hen i'th'forehead.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Geron. th'art welcom. Thou ſtill keepſt thy humor,
Thy travels ha'not chang'd thee. Thou cameſt home
As wiſe as thou wentſt out.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So Whilome ſaid,
A miſer, having much increas'd his ſtore,
He had as much ſtill as he had before.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Enough, I'le give thee over.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O my dear off-ſpring; every ſight of you
Is a new recompence, and ſatisfaction
For all the pain and travel of your birth.
In you your fathers memory ſhall live
Beyond the malice of the grave and death:
And I, when my rejoycing ſhall be full,
And cannot take addition, freely yeelding
My fleſh to duſt, ſhall yet be bleſt by thoſe
VVho ſhall give teſtimony to your vertue.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Twere a ſufficient ſpur to noble actions
To be rewarded but with your content,
Which to procure we make our buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your brow is clouded. Has the Oracle
Adjudg'd againſt you. Pray let us partake
The knowledge of the Delphian decree;
And which of you ſtands higheſt in the favour
Of wiſe Apollo, to be husband to
Princeſſe Eudyna here the Kingdoms heir.
What ſpeaks the Oracle?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Such a Verdict, Madam,
Requires an O Edipus to conſtrue it.
I neither know't, nor am ſolicitous
After the meaning.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Wiſely ſpoken, Pupil.
So Whilome anſwered an Aegyptian Porter
To one demanding what he bore conceal'd?
Tis therefore cover'd that thou ſhouldſt not know▪
The caſes are alike.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Pray let us hear it.
Cannot your Tutor Geron play the Hermes
T'interpret it?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I am not Aenigmatical:
But all for Apothegmes. Beſides, I ſay
(As Whilome Ariſtippus of a Riddle)
It is not ſafe to looſe what being bound
Doth trouble us ſo much.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Yes by all means: For as one Whilome ſaid
The blinde are beſt i'th' dark.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My Lord, your trumps
Are ever ſhot at me. Blinde as I am,
I perceive that. And make much of your Riddle,
I know both what it can and will come to,
Better without the ſight of it, then all
You can, with all your wiſe conſtructions.
And ſo I leave you.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Not in anger, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Madam, you know I know. I muſt take leave
To take a Nap▪

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: And Governour Geron, wait upon your mother,
Truſt our cares with your charge.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So Whilome ſaid
A School boy, when another rais'd his top,
Let me alone, my ſelf can keep it up.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: And now let me entreat that we may hear
The hidden ſentence. Happily ſo many
May gueſſe at the intent.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: She longs to hear
Which of the two is prickt to be her husband.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here it is. If there be any thing.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Let me be Clerk. I hope at leaſt to read it.

l.hi: Contend not for the Jewel, which
Ere long ſhall both of you enrich.
Purſue your Fortune: For tis ſhe
Shall make you what you ſeem to be.

sp.l: Apollo, thy great wiſdom hath quite fool'd mine.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Nothing but contradictions.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: As how, Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: He commands here.

l.hi: Contend not for the Jewel—we agree,

sp.l: Eudyna is the Jewel.—which ſhall both of you enrich.
How ſhall ſhe enrichus both? Can ſhe be wife to us both?
Then here he bids
Purſue your Fortune.—And we both agree
Eudyna is that Fortune too: ſhe's both
The Jewel we muſt not contend for; and
The Fortune we muſt both purſue. Then here
He ſayes tis ſhe ſhall make us what we ſeem to be.
What do we ſeem? we are no Hypocrites
In fleſh or ſpirit; no phantaſtick bodies
Or ſhadows of humanity.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: No, Delphos is but a den of jugglers, which profanely
Abuſe divinity, and pretend a God
Their Patron to authorize their deluſions.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Nephews, the Gods had need be cautilous
For what they ſpeak if you may be their Judges.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What thinks good Juſtinius?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: My Lords, here's two commands;
One, that you not contend to gain the jewel;
The other, that you both purſue your fortune.
Both theſe commands are thus to be obey'd;
Contend not for her as to violate
Your unexampled friendſhip, which you are
Renown'd for ore all Greece; And both purſue
Your fortune in her without eithers grudge,
At tothers happineſs in her choice.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Noble Juſtinius, thanks.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: This we can do.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: And for the happineſs which we both aſpire to
We here confirm the friendſhip long ſince plighted,
Which never ſhall be broken by Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Noble Philargus.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: So vows Philocles,
'Tis not the cloudy language of the Gods
Shall make our breaſts tempeſtuous or ſtormy:
But with the ſame ſerenity and quiet,
As heretofore our hearts ſhall mingle ſtill,
And fortifie their truce. Let the event
Expound their Ridle. If good, it is our merit;
If bad, we know our vertue can correct it.
Mean time Philargus take the word of Philocles,
That though there be no happineſs on earth
I can eſteem above Philargus friendſhip,
But fair Eudyna's love, which onely is
The treaſure I can covet from Philargus;
And cannot look to live but to enjoy it
Rather then juſtle with his friendſhip, I
Will die to loſe it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Noble Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: You have made my vow, my brother Philocles,
And friend, which is above it. I will ſeek
And rather die then fail to gain her love:
But that, and the whole kingdom in addition
Muſt divide our friendſhip or affection.
As we are Twins in birth, we'le be in mind
Unto our lateſt breath. Let Greece hereafter
Forget to mention the Tyndarides
With their alternate Deities, and tell
Of two Theſſalian brothers could refuſe
A happineſs (which onely is not Heaven)
In deteſtation of priority;
Would not be happy, 'cauſe they might not ſhare
An individual, both Time and Thing.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Love, and ambition (I have heard men ſay)
Admit no fellowſhip; It holds not here.
Theſe will have neither wife nor crown alone.
They each deſire my love; but neither can
Enjoy't unleſs he were the other man.
My love is doubly tane, yet muſt gain neither,
Unleſs I could enjoy them both together. O, ye Gods!
Why made ye them two perſons, and aſſign'd
To both but one inſeparable mind?
Or, why was I mark'd out to be that one,
That loves and muſt embrace, or two, or none;
O my perplexity.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Look to the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Madam. How fares the life of goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She ſinks. Dear Mother, Siſter; bring your aids.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: To keep the world alive give your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Ye Gods be now auſpicious.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: A love-qualm.
To bed with her and call for Cupids aid,
He beſt can cure the wound that he has made.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: My Lesbia, my Cinthia, my Licoris
Or (which is beſt of names) my lovely Doris—that●. I.
I ſtill am thine and cannot commutate,
I am as certain to thee as thy fate.
Tis not my ſtudy, or my travails can
Make me to thee appear another man:
Thou may'ſt affirm of me as Whilom did
Xantippe of her husband whom ſhe chid,
Grave Socrates regardleſs of his worth
He ſtill return'd the ſame that he went forth.
Before I viſit thee, thus may'ſt thou hear on
Thine in the tribulation of love—Geron.
Ha, ha, ha. Old Whilom Geron,! art thou come again?
Could Delphos not detain, nor the Sea ſwallow thee
But I muſt be in danger to be puniſh'd
With the porcupine briſtles? Fate deliver me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Doris, you muſt be vigilant in attendance,
And ſee that no man paſs this lobby, towards
Her graces lodging. Tis your charge: look to't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Miſtreſs you know your Mother laid that charge
On me before, and I am ready here
To anſwer every commer in his kind
Had you forgot it?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pardon me, I had;
But my care hurts not. One thing more good Doris.
If my dear brother Philocles come to viſit,
Prithe call me. Speak, wilt thou.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: —help your head.
I muſt not ſtir from hence, yet I muſt come
To call you forth. Away, ſome body comes.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I truſt unto thee Doris.

lg.l: What a ſick Court is here? Shee's love-ſtruck too.
I can with half a ſenſe find her diſeaſe;
But cannot gueſs the object of her love.
She keeps the fire ſo cloſe up in her boſom,
That ſhe will ſooner periſh by't, then ſuffer
A ſpark of it flie out to make diſcovery.
The Princeſs ſhe's love-ſick for two; and her
Deſpair of gaining either's her conſumption.
But what think I of their loves, when mine own
Is trouble enough? Now the viſitants;
My great Lords Howdies are upon the entry,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good morrow Lady.
May I crave admittance to the Lady Governeſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, you may crave it Sir, But not obtain it:
Her nearneſs to the Princeſs at this time
Is by ſo ſtrict neceſſity requir'd.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: May I prevail then, to impart the duty
I have in charge, unto the Ladies daughter?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That is the Miſtriſs whom I wait upon,
Though now at remote diſtance: She attends
Her Mother at this inſtant, and her Mother
The Princeſs in much privacy. If I
May be thought worthy to receive the knowledge
Of what you have in truſt unto the Princeſs,
It ſhall be orderly convey'd unto her Grace.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Lord Stratoeles, ſolicitous for glad tydings,
(Beſeeching that her Grace be pleas'd to take
The tender of his ſervice; and affirming
Upon his honour that no reſt affects him
Until he ſhall receive a perfect knowledge
Of her recovery) prayes to be advertis'd
In what condition of health ſhe fares;
Or to gain leave to viſit her himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, you have loſt much time: you might have ſaid
How does the Princeſs? And I anſwer thus,
She is moſt dangerouſly ſick; not to be ſeen
By him or any man.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yet let her know
My Lords obſequious care for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'le tell my Miſtriſs, who ſhall certifie
Unto my Lady, who ſhall intimate
Unto the Princeſs what you have left in truſt
With me, her Graces hand-maid thrice remov'd.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I will acquaint my Lord; who for your care
Shall upon his advancement to the Crown
Give me command, who will give preſent order
Unto my man for your promotion.
Your diligence deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My great Lords eſpecially paraſite. I am beholden to you.
Here comes another; an importunate,
Though impertinent ſuitor of mine own.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My beauteous Doris, firſt my love preſented
Unto your ſelf, my Lord Philargus craves
To know how fares the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This comes nearer
To my regard then tother; and deſerves
A comfortabler anſwer. She's not well Sir,
But much amended in her health. 'Tis like,
Your Lord (would he approach to viſit her)
Shall find a fair admiſſion to her Grace.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare not (to delay my Lord a minute
Of theſe glad tidings.) Stay to proſecute
My love-ſuit to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, no; away.
Away good Terſulus; and hazard not
Your Lords, for your own fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Yet my Doris—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yet again man.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to think of me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I ſhall, and better of you when you are gone.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Wing'd with that hope, I fly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A pretty nimble fellow and a Taylor.
I could almoſt affect him, did not this
More ſupple handed Barber put him by.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Sweet Doris! thus, by me Lord Philocles
Salutes the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This requires an anſwer
Of health indeed.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: How fares her highneſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Well. Exce●ding well, and longs to ſee your Lord.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'le haſt to tell him ſo

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, good Varillus,
I have not gain'd a conference with you
Since your return from Delphos.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: At more leaſure
I'le tell thee wonders, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Something now.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Ha'you ſeen your lover Geron, the old tutor,
Since our arival?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Here is an Epiſtle
Came from him to my hands this morning. Hang him.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Well: he has been the whole mirth of our journey
In the diſcovery of his love to you.
His meat, his drink, his talk, his ſleep, has all
Been Doris, Doris, nothing but your remembrance
Has been the trouble of his company;
Ile tell thee at large hereafter. The fair Princeſs
Is well you ſay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: She was well when I left her,
But ſubject to much paſſion: She is well
And ill, and well again all in three minutes.
Great Ladies may be ſo. But if I ſhould
B● ſick and well, and ſick again and well
Again as oft as ſhe; the world would ſay
I had it—And had been a courtier, to ſome purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: They would ſay the Handmaid had been handled ſo.
Would they?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Like enough, but great ones muſt not be talk'd on

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You have detain'd me to my undoing.
See, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ile ſend his ſiſter to appeaſe him.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: You have done ill Varillus to neglect
A duty of that conſequence, that I
Expected in your quick return, was this
A time to loyter?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: My good Lord, the princeſs
Is well again; reſtor'd to abſolute health.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Tis happy news. But why was I delay'd
In this accompt? was it too precious for me?
Redeem your fault by ſome inſuing ſervice,
Or you may loſe a maſter, that has lov'd you.
I muſt proceed to gain Eudinas love
From my Philargus or l looſe my ſelf.
And gaining it, I muſt ſorgo Philargus,
And equally be loſt. O ſiſter, welcome.
I muſt requeſt your aid.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: In any thing
Wherein I may be uſeful, beſt of brothers.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I would intreat you be my advocate
In love unto Eudina.—O, but hold,
Shall I be treacherous unto my brother?
A brother! What's a brother? A meer name;
A title which we give to thoſe that lodg'd
In the ſame womb; ſo bedfellowes are brothers;
So men, inhabiting one town, or countrey
Are brothers too: for though the place containing
Be greater, the relation is the ſame.
A friend! I that's the thing I violate,
Then which, nor earth nor heaven hath ought more ſa|cred▪
Tis my Philargus, nay my ſelf I injure,
If I content my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why, brother Philocles—
Did I ſay brother? How my tongue conſpires
To torture me! If Brother be a naked
Title or name (as he ſuggeſts) I would
It had nor being, name, nor title. Philocles
Y'are paſſionate.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Fond reaſon I diſclaim thee,
Love is a ſtrain beyond thee, and approaches
The Gods eſtate: Friendſhip's a moral vertue
Fitter ●r diſputation, then obſervance.
Eudina. O Eudina! In what price
Art thou with me, for whom I caſt away
The Souls whole treaſury Reaſon and Vertue?
Placilla, you muſt wo Eudina for me.
Do you ſtartle at it? Pray do't, as you love me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If I were ſhe you ſhould not need an advocate.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I charge you by this kiſs.—

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your wages
Corrupts your agent to be falſe. O whither;
Into what Sands will the raſh Pilot, Love?
Drive this weak veſſel? did I call it Love?
Tis ſooty, helliſh fire; unlawful flame:
Yet ſuch as we may eaſier tax, then tame.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: What troubles you Placilla? O you are
Already entertain'd to mediate
For him you better love, Philargus, do:
He beſt deſerves her; Ile wo for him too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, my Lady calls for you? My Lord
The Princeſs has tane notice of your viſit
And wiſhes you draw nearer if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I meet that wiſh with ſwift, but fearful feet.
My joyes are bitter, and my woes are ſweet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have heard men ſay when they on gameſters look
(Though equally affected to both parties,
Or both were ſtrangers to'em yet) they'l yeeld
A ſecret inclination which ſhould win.
I am for Philocles, now, againſt Philargus,
Who is as noble, and as free to me,
As ever Philocles was. But tarry Doris;
You have a bett upon the game I take it,
Your love unto Varillus. If his Lord
Riſe to a Kingdom, you may hope to climbe
The ladder of a Ladyſhip by the man.
But not too faſt: Here's one purſues the game
That is as like to win. Why if he does?
His follower Terſulus loves me paſt Varillus,
And may as much advance me. But I love not
Him, And the love of honour above husbands
Has been ſo common among Ladies, that
The faſhions ſtale and ougly.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: So't muſt be.
And ſo by tranſpoſition of my love
I ſhall be quiet, and Philocles doubly happy.
Doris, go ſeek my mother, and perceive
If I may ſee the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Love, thou art well compar'd to fire, which where
It doth obey and ſerve being commanded
By higher powers of the ſoul, it fares
Like to the ſtone or jewel of a ring,
Which joyns the orb, and gives it price and luſter:
So glorious is that love, ſo neceſſary.
But, where it rules and is predominant,
It tiranizeth; Reaſon is impriſon'd;
The will confined; and the memory
(The treaſury of notions) clean exhauſted;
And all the ſences ſlaviſhly chain'd up
To act th'injunctions of inſulting love,
Pearch'd on the beauty of a woman. Thou
Maſculine love, known by the name of friendſhip
Art peaceful and morigerous: But that
Of woman, is imperious and cruel.
VVhy ſhould I then loſe Philocles for Eudina?
sp.stage: Ent. Eudi|na. Thymile Eudi. rea|ding a letter.
sp.l: Why? Can I look on her and ask a Reaſon?
O the divinity of woman! ſure
There is no heaven without'em. If the Gods
Should thruſt out Jove as he depos'▪l his Father
And elect me to be their thonderer
I'ld not drink Nectar to forgo Eudina.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Fie, fie Philargus, y'are a ſſugiſh Lover.
I have been careful for you, yea and partial
Againſt your brother Philocles, to prefer
Your love to his: And you to ſuffer him
A whole hour opportunity before you!

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Has he been here?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And is. Onely for you
I have beguil'd him of her preſence, that
Till you have made firſt preſentation
Of love to her he ſhall have no acceſs.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Now Philocles, I ſuffer in thy injury;
And to proceed in it were treachery.
I would retire—But that magnetique beauty
To which are chain'd thouſands of hearts and eyes
Has captiv'd mine: nor muſt I ſeem to ſlight
A mothers care. She's not the firſt (tis known)
That of two ſons hath beſt affected one.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Why move you not Philargus towards the Prin|ceſſe.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Madam, you ſee ſhe's buſy.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: May thy ambition hoiſt thee into air;
And thy looſe wings, like thy licentious paper,
There failing thee, let fall thy vicious body
To earth, as here thy name lies to be trod on.
Philargus, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Princely Madam,
That language from your gracious lips is powerful
To ſave him from the grave, that onely lives
By your free favours.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Nay, my dear Philargus,
I thought me nearer to you, then that you
Should rove at me with Courtſhip. Stratocles
(The emblem of whoſe pride lies there in paper)
Shot from afar indeed; yet, like a Jove
(A ſelf-conceited one) preſum'd to ſtrike
Love by command into me by his Letters.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I cannot flatter pride, nor undervalue
Abilities. 'Tis true that Siratocles
Has been a uſeful ſervant to the State;
But, doubtleſs, he would make as ill a Maſter.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: No more of him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Nor more be thought of him.
And therefore Madam, by your fair command,
To avoid all Court-circumlocutions,
I tender thus my ſervice, and crave hearing.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You have it freely.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: To avoid all lets,
I will withdraw my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The King has graciouſly been pleas'd, in lieu
Of my ſlain fathers ſervices; and for love
To us his ſons, (by us much undeſerv'd)
To recommend unto your noble choice
My brother and my ſelf. You ſtanding doubtful
Whether to chuſe, we to avoid diſpute
Of violating friendſhip, did implore
The Councel of the Oracle to direct
You in th'election. But the hidden ſence
In the dark ſentence hath perplext both you
And us with more anxiety.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: It is too true.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Yet you are not preſcrib'd; your choice is free.
To take your lot in Philocles or me.
We both, by ſtrong injunction muſt purſue
Your ſacred Love, yet keep our friendſhip true.
Then thus illuſtrious Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Not ſo low.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: As low as future duty muſt compel me,
When you ſhall be my Queen, let me beſeech
The favour that I ſeek and would obtain,
Equal with heavenly bliſs, to ſhine on Philocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: That he may be your King?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: May he prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Be all example loſt.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Friendſhip, with favour, may
Hold between King and Subject: But one throne
Cannot eſtate two Kings; Love's number's one.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O my Philargus, you have open'd now
The meaning of the Oracle. I have the ſence
Moſt perfectly. You have beyond example
Preſerv'd your friendſhip with your brother; and
In wooing for him have won me to your ſelf.
I am your own.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I am amidſt the Gods.
The wealth o'th'world, the beauty of the Heavens,
And powers of both ſhall not redeem my intereſt.
—Provided that I loſe not Philocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: In that your conſtancy you win me more.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your importunity hath prevail'd. See Philocles,
The Princeis, and Philargus.

sp.speaker: Philoe.
sp.l: O, you are partial.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O help, my brother; ſpeak, dear Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Ye Gods, how comes this? Let me raiſe him up,
Brother, and friend; ſpeak, 'tis Philargus calls thee.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Philargus, let me go. 'Tis your advantage.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Let me requeſt the cauſe of your diſturbance,
Good Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: No other but my ſelf.
Honour'd Eudyna: For, who feeds to danger
Upon a diſh he loves, ought not to blame
The meat, but his unbridled appetite.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How do you now? What a cold moiſture
Spreads ore his temples here.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Let me come to him:

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I can read his grief.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What's that to the redreſs?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: The Delphian God, medcines inventor knowes
That and not I.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: His grief's a jealous paſſion
Upon my ſuppos'd favour to Philargus.
Shake it off Philocles, I am thine, as much
As ere I was, or his.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: It is no jealouſy
Onely a fear Philargus had broke friendſhip:
So, my ſouls better part exited, left
The other languiſhing.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Had you expir'd
In that belief, and I had underſtood it,
My ſhadow ſhould have poſted after yours
Unto the Eliſian fields to vindicate
So cauſeleſs imputation.

sp.speaker: Thy:
sp.l: And becauſe
You charg'd my ſon with partiallity
Let us remove, Philargus, come Placilla.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You will not take him from me. Stay Philargus.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What would you do with both?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I may not ſtir,
When ſhe, whoſe power above me countermands
The precepts of the Gods requires my ſtay.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What not to give you brother Philocles
An opportunity for equal hearing?
Your grace will not deney't him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: True, I may not.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: That ſpell convinces all. Friendſhips above,
And muſt controul obedience, and love.
Tis not to injure thee my dear Philargus,
That here I linger, to oppoſe thy love;
But to prefer it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What ſayes Philocles?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: To ſay I love you, Madam, with a zeal
That dares to meet the tryal of Martyrdom,
And ſuffer't for your ſake, might get a name,
A glorious one, and an immortal Crown:
Yet ſo I ſhould forgo (in leaving you
On earth, a heaven on it) the bliſs,
Which, grieving, I ſhould in Eliſium miſs.
No, I will love you better then to die,
And be mine own chief mourner; yet muſt crave,
Under your gracious favour, leave to ſuffer
More then a thouſand deaths, that is, to live
And part with my fair hopes in you for ever.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What means my Philocles?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Princely Madam,
Conſider the neceſſity, which now
By further ſearch I gather from the hidden
Oraculous perduit; by which I am tied
Not to contend for you, that is, I muſt not
Wound friendſhip in Philargus: B●t purſue
My fortune, which is to gain love from you.
For whom it ſayes not, but the meanings plain,
I for Philargus ſhould your love obtain.
The Gods deal after as they pleaſe with me,
My ſute is that you take Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O—
Philocles you have made a double conqueſt
For you have got the victory of me
Which was before aſſign'd unto Philargus.
Your fortune thus embraces you

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: This now,
And with Philargus friendſhip were to me
A fortune 'bove the envy of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: He cannot diſallow't. He woo'd me for you,
And won me to himſelf, as you have now
Suing for him.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I muſt not hold you then.
His title, as his friendſhip precedes mine.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Yet ſtill the choice is mine. I may take you
Without offence to him. But now he comes,
And has again an equal intereſt,
Strange love! In others abſence I took either
And lov'd each beſt; Now both at once appear,
Neither is mine. Fate, let me die to one
Rather then live in this confuſion.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now Madam, whethers love do you approve.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Confound me not with queſtion. They are each
Wedded to others friendſhip: Either is
More ſtudious for the other then himſelf.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: And ever muſt.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: And will be.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: So will I
For both of you then for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Alaſs.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Then let's continue thus with Maiden love,
With modeſt freedom, unſuſpected joyes,
As we had all been formed in one womb,
Till Heaven determine of us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To determine
Of you Eudyna, is by heaven committed
In preſent unto me. On you depends
The future glory and proſperity,
Both of my houſe and Kingdom. Tis beſides,
Exacted of me by my near Allies,
And by my Subjects (whom I muſt ſecure)
To conſtitute a Succeſſor: And no longer
Will I expect your anſwer, then five dayes.
By then you muſt declare who is your husband;
Or elſe expect one from my ſelf; the man
Whoſe name I am as loth to mention
As you to hear, even Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Nay, death firſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be you obedient; and by the way,
Take my approvement of Lord Philocles,
Not that I ſlight Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Here's a myſtery too,
As dark as that from Delphos. He approves
My choice of Philocles, ſlighting not Philargus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come both you equal brothers; leave her to
Her thoughts a while.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: In all obedience.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What ſtrange amazement hath ſurpriz'd you Ma|dam?
No ſtudy, nor no ſtrife can alter fate
Or the decrees, the Gods determinate.
A husband you ſhall have, be confident.
Be, as you were; ſecure of the event,
Till time produce it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam, be your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Yet five dayes for love's war. Jove grant I have
By then, to end the ſtrife, a peaceful grave.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Would you thus offer, by your own diſeaſe
To ſhorten your Mothers dayes? Or can you pine
And I not grieve? or cannot grief kill me
Do you think?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A wiſe Philoſopher Whilome did affirm,
That women who have paſt the fire of love
Have hearts, which grief can neither pierce, ne move.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Son, your Philoſophy fails you, as your love
Blinds you: For Cupids fire I know may be
Quench'd by old age: But grief's unquenchable.
My tongue ſtill falters with me (there's my grief)
And there are not ſo many fadoms 'twixt
A womans tongue and heart, but grief may find
The bottom, but for care to keep it up
By ſending down an Antidote before it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But Whilom did the love-ſick Poet prove,
No antidote againſt the power of Love.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Forbear your Whiloms, and your old ſaid ſaws,
And ſince you are in love, and by that love
Grown ſick with the concealment.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As Whilom
Th' Athenian boy who ſtole a fox did hide
Under his coat his theft from being deſcried
Until it tore his Gentals—his intrals
I ſhould have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: No more I ſay
Of your diſeaſe, but to the cure, which is
The love of Doris. How ha'you try'd her, ſon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By oratory, Epiſtles, and by gifts
Which Whilome Ovid ſaid were beſt of ſhifts.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yes, ſuch a gift it might be, and ſo faſtened.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But ſhe, as Whilom ſaid Anominus
Retorteth all with ſcorn injurious.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yet will you leave your Whiloms? And go ſeek
My Lady Governeſs? ſay I would ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But Whilome ſaid Diogenes (tis true)
To one that would, I will not ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Will you ſay as I ſay; and do as y'are bidden?
It is not her great Lady-ſhips daughters hand-maid
Shall ſcorn my ſon while I know what I know.
If you love Doris, run and tell her ſo.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For Doris love, as Whilome Daedalus.
I will take wing. But ſee I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O Garrula! well found, I was in queſt of you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And I was eene a ſending for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What an imperious beldam's this. But I
Muſt humour her. Sending for me do you ſay?
For what, good Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Sending for you? Yes Madam, ſo I ſaid,
And ſai't again. What, what, I know what I know.
You know I do; and that there is no ſuch
Diſtinction 'twixt the honours of your birth
And place; and mine of age and knowledge, but
You might vouchſafe the ſummons when I ſend.

sp.speaker: Thy,
sp.l: What needs this Garrula? I am here you ſee.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You know I know, and have deſerv'd ſome favors,
I do not boſt for what. You know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O me!
Who truſt thoſe ſecrets whereon honour reſts
To cuſtody in Mercenary breaſts
Do ſlave nobility; and though they pay
A daily ranſom, nere redem't away.
Pray let us be more private, though indeed
I love your ſon for his great care of mine.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: O, do you ſo? Go forth ſon Geron, till
I call. All ſhall go well Ile warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Whilom, ſo
Said a Phyſitian, meaning to reſtore,
And kill'd the Patient was but ſick before.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Why Garrula do you maintain a ſtrife
Still in my grieved mind 'twixt hope and fear?
Cannot ſo many years of my known kindneſs
Win yet a confidence of ſecrefie.
You are as deeply bound by oath too as my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I do confeſs my oath, and would not break it;
Yet, Madam, as you are a woman, you
May know a broken oath is no ſuch burthen
As a great ſecret is; beſides the tickling
A woman has to in and out with't. Oh
The tongue itche is intollerable! And were I
A woman of tongue, as moſt are of my calling
(Though Midwives ha'been held the beſt at ſecret
Co●ncel keeping) it had been out I fear.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: But ſtill take heed dear Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yes Madam.
Yet there are kindneſſes requir'd on your part.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Have I not ſtill been kind?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My memory ſerves me; and but that my tongue
Now falters with me—I could recount
All the rewards I have had from time to time,
Since you tranſlated me from a Country houſwife,
Into the Midwife Royal; what in Gowns,
In Gold, in Jewels, Chains and Rings; and (which
I prize'bove all) my ſyrrops and my ſippings.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your place of honour in the Court—

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: What, what?
I hope I had that before i'che Kings favour,
As his Queens Midwife. She is in Eliſium.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Then Garrula your learned ſons preferment,
Tutor and Governour to my Sons.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Thereby
Hangs a tale, Madam. Now I come to th'point;
My ſon affects your daughters hand-maid Doris,
Who ſlights his love. I muſt now by your power
Obtain her for my Son.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Be confident,
Though I confeſs I hold her worthleſs of him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I tell him ſo: But love has blinded him.
Ho Geron, I ſay Geron, come and hear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So Whilome priſoners have been cal'd to come
From dungeon deep to hear a blacker doom.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Geron, be comforted. By all my power,
Doris ſhall be your own.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then Whilome, as
Ovid his Corynna ſweet, ſaid o—
She comes, ſhe comes. My joyes do overflow.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now Doris, what portends your haſt? Speak Maid,
Is it to Geron, or to me, your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: His ill looks, had almoſt made me miſcarry'c.
Madam, the Princeſs inſtantly deſires
Your company.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: But by her Graces favour,
And your leave, Doris, I will trench ſo far
On both your patiences, and for your good,
As to be witneſs of an interchange
Of ſome few words twixt Geron and your ſelf.
Why look you from him ſo? he loves you, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That's more then I ere knew, or read, by all
He ſpeaks or writes to me. He cloaths his words
In furres and hoods, ſo, that I cannot find
The naked meaning of his buſineſs, Madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Speak plainly to her, Geron.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: To her Son.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My buſineſs is the ſame, that Whilome drew
Demoſthenes to Corinth, ſome repentance,
So I pay not too dear.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lo you there, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You muſt ſpeak plainer, Son.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And be you kinder, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But not ſo kind, good Madam, as to grant
I know not what.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O forfeit not the praiſe
That Whilome Aristotle gave your Sex,
To be inrich'd with piety and pitty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not what to pitty, but your want
Of utterance. It is ſome horrid thing
That you deſire, and are aſham'd to ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No, gentle Doris, nothing but the thing,
Whereby great Alexander Whilome ſaid,
He knew himſelf a mortal, and no God,
Coition—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Be it what it will; I cannot
Give what I underſtand not. Y'are too aloof.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: There's comfort, Son. And I'le give thee inſtru|ctions
To come more cloſe to her.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I'le eaſe your care,
And be my ſelf his Agent. Hee's too learned,
Geron, you ſpeak too learnedly, as if
You woo'd a Muſe: And Doris underſtands not,
But by your poſture, what you'ld have. I'le put
Your meaning into womans words; and ſuch
As ſhall be ſure to ſpeed. But firſt I'le wait
Upon the Princeſs. Garrula, will you go?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And thank you for my Son: But ſtill—I know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Nay, I will do't Geron, be confident.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I thank your Ladyſhip as much as they
Who Whilome —Whilome—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Knew not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: He's overjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Go Geron, lead the way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray trouble me no further. I have ſaid,
That if in five dayes ſpace ſhe make not choice
Of one of thoſe whom (I muſt tell you Stratocles)
She loves, and I prefer before you, then
I'le weigh your ſuit, and reaſons; and till then
I ſay't again, you are a trouble to me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A trouble Sir? That were a time that knew me,
A trouble to your enemies, not you,
When this ſame lump of earth (which now's a trouble)
Stood a ſole Bulwark of your Realm; repelling
Arms of foes; ſhrowding your fearful Subjects
Under my ſhield; guarding your fields and Vineyards
From deſolation; your Palaces from ruine;
And am I now a trouble?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: You loſe the glory of your deeds by blazing
Your own renown. He that commends himſelf,
Speaks upon truſt, and is his hearers ſlave.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Peace, envy, and be thankful for thy life
Which thy tongue forfeits.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Let my mildneſs tell you,
You are irreverent before the King,
Who has not been forgetful of your worth,
Nor ſlow in your reward. Then moderate
Your heat with counſel; and be firſt aſſiſtant
Unto the publick good: So ſhall you merit
The firſt regard in honours and affairs
Of private nature.

sp.speaker: Sra.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This Oracle
Troubles me not a little. I had thought
Thereby to have declin'd this weighty care
From my declining ſhoulders, and have given
My countrey ſatisfaction, and my ſelf,
In chuſing of a ſon and ſucceſſor.
But I am priſoner in the Labyrinth
Of the Gods verdict.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Their ſublimity
In matters of the future ſeldom ſtoops
To humane apprehenſion; yet vouchſafes
To anſwer our demands: but chides withall
Our too much incenſs with obſcurity.
Your grace however may preſume, where they
Shal deign to ſpend a word, and take an offering,
It is a certain augury of good.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou haſt allay'd my fear. Justinus come,
Lead me thy brains aſſiſtance. For in thee
I find a temper that accords with me.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Souldler, I dare yet tell thee thou art raſh;
Fooliſh as valliant; and as eaſily may'ſt
For all thy loſtineſs be undermin'd
As the baſe bramble: Boaſting weakneſs, thee
And promiſing Ambition leads thee up
An earthly exhalation into th'air;
Where with a little borrow'd light, one moment,
Thou ſhin'ſt the mark and wonder of all eyes;
But ſoon conſum'd and darted to the Center,
Becom'ſt the ſcorn of men and ſport of Children.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You are oth ſect of Cinicks, and have learn'd
To bark Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Then ſhall you hear
Your now adorning multitude upbraid
Your inſolence and pride, and gain the name
Of Prophets by your downfall, while one ſwears
He had foretold it long; Another dreampt it;
All joyntly cry we never could indure him;
See what a look he has; what brawny lips;
What poyſonous eyes; and what an impudent front!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You will out-run your priviledge of prating
And ſuffer for't.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I am too prodigal
Of ſeed upon ſo flinty ſoyl as thou.
Be as thou art, and periſh.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ignorant wretch,
That out of all thy bookiſh Theory
Knowes not the ſoul to be Aerial
And of a ſoaring nature; not unlike
The noble Falcon that will never ceaſe
To work 'bove all that tops her. The ſupream
Eſtate on earth, and next unto the Gods
Is majeſty; and that's my preſent gain,
Though I have all but that, yet wanting that
All is as none to me: And ſince my way
Muſt be upon the Ruins (ſowre Diſanius)
Of thee, and of thy glories in thy Nephews
The Kings dear darlings, for whoſe pretious ſakes
I muſt attend five dayes (yet be a trouble)
I'le travail through your bloods: Thy ſelf has gi'n me
The quicker motion by thy timely envy.
Thou haſt ſet ſpurs to the pale horſe of death,
That into duſt ſhall trample all thoſe lets
Which ſtand twixt me and the Theſſalian Crown,
Upon whoſe back I'le ſet this Rider.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My ſoveraign Lord.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I like that compellation:
Thou ſtil'ſt me as thou wiſheſt me, on whom
Depends thy conſequent advancement, Matho.
But we but dream of ſoveraignty and ſleep
To the Atchievement: ſomething muſt be done
With waekful eyes and ready hands my Matho.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now my King ſpeaks himſelf. Let but your eye
Find out the way theſe ready hands ſhall act
The ſtrength of your deſigns. I can perceive
That now the labour of your Jove-like brain
Is bringing forth the Pallas, ſhall inſpire
Me, to perform the work of my advancement.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Tis not yet ripe for the delivery,
But thou ſhalt quickly have it. Follow me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good Madam, let me be excus'd. The mirth
You offer'd to allay or quench my ſorrows
Might have been well receiv'd at former times:
But now it is unſeaſonable.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet think on't, Madam,
How gravely Geron goes, and with what ſcorn
The wanton Girl recoyles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good, ſpeak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Then Beldame Garrula's reaſons urging Doris▪
Shewing how either of his pupils grace
In your electing Philocles or Philargus,
Though to them doubtful, is a ſure advancement
To her by Geron.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Still you move like thoſe
That do in merry tales mis-ſpend their breath
To thoſe that are that day mark'd out for death.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may not ſay ſo (Madam) tis in you
By taking one, to give new life to two;
Your ſelf, and if you'l give me leave to name
The other, be it Philargus: or, if chance
Shall favour better, Philocles or him,
Let it be him that gives you the firſt viſit.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: That were to fancy in our ſelves an Oracle;
Or to give fortune power, to execute
The judgement of the Delphian God.

sp.speaker: Thy
sp.l: Who knowes
But that his Oracle would have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Was it for that you now ſent for Philargus.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Say, ſhall it be ſo Madam; or ſuppoſe ſo?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: This pleaſes better yet then Gerons wooing.
Praythee Placilla ſing. And may thy voice
Attract him that may prove the happier choice.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ile try my beſt in notes, and what they want
Ile ſtrive to make effectual in my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thanks kind Placilla.—But the leaden weights
Of ſleep oppreſs mine eye-lids, and I ſhall not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet ſit, and let her ſing: you'l ſleep the better.
sp.stage: Placilla Sings. After a ſtrain or two, Eudina ſleeps, and enters, as a viſion at the ſeveral doors, Philargus and Philocles; They meet and embrace affectionately: then whiſper a while: Then ſudenly ſtart off, and draw their ſwords: menace each other, and ſeverally depart. The ſong ended, Eudina affrightedly ſtarts up.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Stay Philocles, ſtay Philargus. Let not fury
Lead you to end that difference with your ſwords,
Which onely fits my life to ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What means your Grace.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Purſu'em, with prevention,
Before they meet again, or one or both
Muſt periſh; did you not obſerve their challenge,
And eithers daring other to the field?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Who Madam, where? and when?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Now; here; your ſons.
How can you ask?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Becauſe we were awake
And ſaw nothing.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Collect your ſpirits Madam: you ſlept.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: It was an omenous dream then.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And of good,
I dare divine it Madam. And now ſee
Whom fortune firſt hath ſent to be your choice.
Philargus, you have won the glorious prize.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But dos the glory of the world, Eudina, grant it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: My affrightment ſhakes me ſtill—
O my Philargus, I am now inſpir'd
Sure by a viſion from the Gods, with knowledge,
That, in my choice of you, or Philocles,
I ſhall become the ruin of you both.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Tis not in fate to wound our common friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Tis better in my ſelf to kill the danger.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The Gods avert ſuch purpoſes. If you
Deprive the world of your fair ſelf, then we
Both fall by neceſſary conſequence.
But what are we? This Theſſaly muſt ſuffer.
The King muſt yield, to ſee a new and ſtrange
Succeſſon appointed to his Crown;
And by his ſubjects, not himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Tis that
Deters me: yet let me prevail Philargus
(To quit me of my fears) that ere I paſſe
My faith unto a husband, your and Philocles,
Before the Gods, your Mother, and my ſelf,
Once more, do celebrate your vow of Friendſhip.
And let me be excus'd in this: for I
Muſt tell you, dear Philargus, that tho' now
My love be fixt on one of you (albeit
I name not which) I will not take him with
Leaſt ſcruple of a fear of loſing him
Again by th'others ſpight; nor leave that other
Leſſe lov'd by me, then now he is, for ever;
And tho but one can be poſſeſs'd of me
One friendſhip, yet, muſt marry us all three.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The Gods have ſpoke it in you; it is their
Divine injunction; Madam, I obey it,
And dare engage as much for Philocles.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This is moſt fair: now, till you meet, tis fit
You fall on lighter purpoſes for your health.
Son, here was mirth to day; although the Princeſſe
Reliſh'd it not.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I heard of Gerons love
To his fair Doris. We are now become
His Tutors, Madam, to be amorous.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Placilla, come you hither. I obſerve
A change in you of late; and do ſuſpect
The Reaſon. What! Do you bluſh at my ſuſpition?
Nay then you mak'● my knowledge. You are in Love.
I'le yet come nearer you. I gueſſe with whom:
And at fit time I'le ſchool you for'●.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Come Madam;
Now if you pleaſe wee'l take ſome ayr.
Craves leave to ſeek his brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I wait o'your Grace. Nay, do not look diſpleas'd:
I tell you Girl, there is danger in it.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Stay Placilla.
What! has my Mother chid you. I'le not queſtion
Her Reaſon, nor your fault; but pray thee ſiſter
If Philocles approach to ſee the Princeſſe
Ere my return, tell him I ſtay at's lodging,
Firſt, to confer with him.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I will my brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Introth thou weepſt. Therefore to comfort you,
Becauſe I know by ſome infallible ſignes,
You are more tender of his Love then mine.
He ſtands in equal competition yet
With me for fair Eudina. And if Fortune
Allots her me, I'le be as kind a brother
And ſtil the ſame to you as Philocles.
I pray thee dry thine eyes.
sp.stage: Ent. Matho diſguiſed with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If a diſguis'd face and a counterfeit hand
Ever prevail'd, may theſe in this plot ſpeed.
My Lord, I had this in charge to render to you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I am diſcover'd in my lawleſſe love.
Remember, Cupid, whom thou makeſt thy Anvil;
A poor weak virgin. If thou art a God,
Be juſt and reaſonable: It ſavours not
Of juſtice, to provoke inceſtuous flames,
Nor Reaſon to enforce an Ardency
Of things impoſſible. Let me not burn
With neighbouring fire, which, to enjoy, I muſt
Therefore diſpair becauſe it is ſo near.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Ha! where's this fellow? is he gone?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yes, brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Tis Philocles his hand! An eager challenge!
A challenge, and to me, his friend and Brother.
Now Oracle, where's your Riddle? Anſwer me,
Apollo's fiddle-ſtick. O ye Delphian Prieſts,
You hang religion up, like painted cloaths
Before unſeemly walls, to cloak their filth
And palliate their wicked miſteries.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How do you brother?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Sick in Philocles.
You'l hear more of his kindneſs to you ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He ſuſpects too, with much diſpleaſure, my
Unreaſonable Love to Philocles.
But why ſhould we be Reaſons followers
With loſs of liberty? which of the Creatures
Allayes his heat toward any of his kind,
'Cauſe the ſame belly gave them being? They
Obſerve no difference of Sire, or Dam,
Brother, or Siſter, being mature for love.
Ah, whither am I going? Beſtial thoughts
Forth of my boſom; Leave me not my Soul,
Or my ſoules better part, my reaſon. Oh
It was returning but a flaming ſhaft
Of love has ſet it's Manſion afire
And frights it back again.

sp.speaker: Philoc. Placilla.
sp.l: Siſter.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: That name of Siſter, like a violent cold
Upon an extream heat, feavers my blood
To death.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Me thinks you are ſad and troubled ſiſter.
Why thus alone? Or have you entertain'd
That troubleſome companion, Love? Come tell me
I can adviſe you very learnedly:
For Cupids Scholars are more exquiſite
In giving councel then in uſing it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How ſhall I anſwer him? I dare not look on.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Why are you ſad.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Out of conformity
Unto the preſent garb: I have aſſum'd
Onely a veil of ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Thou art onely happy,
Whoſe ſorrow is but outward, as a ſtranger
Call'd to be preſent at a funeral
Clads himſelf like the reſt, is ſerious,
And ſilent with a countenance dejected,
And Teſtudineous pace; but has not tears,
No groanings for a loſs to him unknown:
The Obſequies performed uncloaths himſelf
Of griefe and weeds together. But my ſiſter,
You are not pleas'd to talk upon this ſubject.
Where is the Princeſs?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He'has given me now a Colour for my ſadneſs.
The Princeſs is retir'd; She has been troubled
With a moſt fearful dream of a Duello
Betwixt you and Philargus to be fought.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: With friendly Courteſies?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Nay, with ſwords ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Philargus hath been with her, and to him
She told her fears, enjoyning him, that both
Of you ſhould come, and jointly before her
Declare your conſtant friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: That's ſoon done.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But truſt me Sir, I fear Philargus took not
All as ſhe meant it; for at his departing,
He look'd diſpleaſedly; and, when I demanded
His healths condition, he ſaid he was ſick
In Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: In Philocles his abſence,
As I am in his. That was his meaning ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pardon my fear; which is, that hee's not friends w'ye.

sp.speaker: Pheloc.
sp.l: Away, your fear has made you idle.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No.
It is my love, in that black horror clad,
Which will, before it leaves me, make me mad.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Ile ſeek him out.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: My Lord, I was commanded
To convey theſe into your Lordſhips hands.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: By whom were you imploy'd?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: My Lord 'twas not
The man that mov'd me. For I know him not;
But the reward. I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: My brother write. Ha! Are we at ſuch diſtance?
Thou art no Propheteſs, Placilla, art thou?
sp.stage: Brother Philocles, we are the laughing ſtock of the Nati|tion; and injurious both to the King, our Countrey, the divine Eudina, and our ſelves, by our childiſh love. The time is ſhort, meet me, (I conjure you by our Friendſhip) within three hours, in the North vale of Tempe; where it ſhall be the Gods election to take one of us, and leave the other for Eudina. Expoſtulate not with your ſelf, much leſs with me otherwiſe then by weapon, or never expect to ſee your Brother Philargus.
sp.l: O Gods and men! where ſhall we go to find
Friendſhip and truth? Bee't ſo: For in th'event
We may be happy both: But with this ods;
One with Eudina, tother with the Gods.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: We ſhould love one another, brother Terſulus,
More inwardly, and be in friendſhip true
As our Lords are. Prithee let their example
Piece up all difference betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Piece up,
I know your meaning and your jear Varillus,
In your piece up.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Fie on thy jealouſie. 'Cauſe thou art a Taylor,
How ere a Gentleman by place, thou think'ſt
I jear thy quality.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You ſhould not. For
Look back unto the worlds beginning; there
Youl' find a Taylor was before a Barber.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Nay if you go to rip up old Antiquity.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Rippe! there he is again.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You may as well
Collect, that the firſt man (who you ſuggeſt
Was his own Taylor) was his own Barber firſt.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Do you think he did not ſcratch his head
In caſting how to faſhion out his breeches?
And that's in part, you know, the Barbers office.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The ſcraching of the head.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And ſtill
In uſe 'mongſt Taylors on themſelves. But note
The foul corruptions brought in by Time;
Of old they did but rub invention up,
How to contrive their work: But now their heads
Wriſts, fingers, all have got an itch by't, which
Nothing but ſtealing can allay; though that
Can never cure it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Lying and ſtealing went
Of old together: now they are ſhar'd it ſeems
Between the Barber and the Taylor.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Sharp.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your inſtruments are ſharp as mine, Sir Barber,
And you can pick more out of your Lords ears
Then I take from his Garments with my ſheers.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Agree good brother, or would we had Doris
To ſtickle twixt us.
There y'are afore me too.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: But come, Lords followers are their Apes in moſt things,
Why ſhould not we be as friendly Rivals, now
In Doris Love, as are our Lords in the
Princeſs Eudinas. We will take up a faſhion.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Varillus, where's your Lord?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I know not Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Terſulus, where's yours?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I know not Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You Eccho one another. Y'are commanded
Both by the Princeſs and the Governeſs
To ſeek'em out.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your love commands our ſtay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Coupled together? Go yet one of you.
You I can ſpare beſt.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Why him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You then.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Why him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you conſpire? I will return your care.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Nay gentle Doris ſtay. For, tis in vain
To ſeek our Lords. They are both rod ſingly forth
To take the Air. Mine an hour ſince.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Mine even now. I came but ſince to call
My brother Terſulus.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your brother Terſulus?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As deeply vow'd in friendſhip as our Lords are.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: It is with us as tis with them: we both
Are brothers, friends; yet Rivals in your love.
Can you now, as the Princeſs is to them,
Be equally affected to us both?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you ſtay me to abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Nay, dear Doris.
We love our Lords? and as you love the Princeſs,
Who loves them, love you us. You are Eudina,
I Philocles, and he Philargus is.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Are the men mad.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Suppoſe ſo Gentle Doris.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: The King commands you to make preſent choice
Of one of us, or elſe ambitious Stratocles
(That's Geron) muſt enjoy you. Now ſweet Princeſs
Be ſpeedy in your choice. The kingdoms good
Depends upon it. And in your Election,
O make Philargus bleſt: He beſt deſerves you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Admired friend, and brother Philocles,
Your courteſie ore-comes me: I muſt ſue,
Though my heart akes the while as much for you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This is fine ſooling—
Good Barber Philocles, and Taylor Philargus,
You ſhall not need to trim up his Affection,
Nor you to ſtich up his with your forc'd courteſies.
I know, in this, each wooes but for himſelf,
And my Affection runs as even betwixt you,
As nothing but your ſizors, or your ſheares
Had parted.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: See Stratocles, alias Geron.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So Whilome did contend two warlike Princes
For a fair ●and, till a powerful King
Subdu'd them both and it. Doris, take heed,
Be wary in your converſation
(As Whilom Tully warn'd his tender ſon)
With ſuch Pl●beians, leaſt their vulgar breeding
Corrupt your education.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Muſt ſhe be
Your pupil learned Geron.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And my ſelf
Her onely ſtudy; ſuch as Whilome was;
Ʋlyſſes to Penelope.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Take heed Doris
How you become his wife: For he will love you
So by the book, as he will never lie with you
Without an Authour for't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe ſhall be
More precious to me then Homers Iliads,
Whilome to Alexander, which he made
His mighty bed-fellow: But why ſtand I
To render this account? The Princeſſe ſent you,
Doris, to call their Lords to walk with her,
And take the air of Tempe.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: They are gone to take the air already, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come you with me then, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And why with you
Antiquity? I have heard you all this while,
And though you boaſt you have an intereſt in me,
We are not yet one volume, both bound up
And claſp'd together.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: She ſpeaks in his Element.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, I am yet looſe paper; and 'twere good
To keep me ſo; for when I'm bound I muſt
Obey, be ſearch'd, examin'd and corrected.
Yet this I'le do, and now be ſerious,
If you will all obey my rule; and try
Your fortunes who ſhall have me.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: We agree.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Their merits bear no aequability
With mine.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: A very Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You boaſt your worth, and ſtand on confidence
In powerful advocates: But what are all
Unto my Love, and (which is more) my will?
If you will hear my propoſition, hear it.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: We are agree'd. Pray hear't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Lets hear it then.
The Gods, in Love, Whilome have ſtoop'd with men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That you all love me, I believe; and am
Content that every one of you do think
Himſelf prime man in my Affection:
And one of you I'le take. But yet my choice
Muſt wait upon Eudina's. Therefore mark
If your Lord wins the Princeſſe, and becomes
The Kings immediate Heir, I will be yours;
If your Lord, yours.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Therein the oddes is mine,
For they are both my Lords.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then if both have her, I'le be yours: not elſe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As Whilome ſaid, None of the wiſeſt Clerks,
When the Sky falls we ſhall have ſtore

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Of Whilomes: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your Miſtreſſe, Lady, Princeſſe, and my Mother
Shall know your.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Away, old Whilome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your Lords too I'le acquaint.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Away, old child,
Go tell it Mother, do.
If you had ſpent, in the Phyloſophers ſchool
Your time no better, then in Cupids Lectures,
What a ſtrange dunce you had been. Tell her, Love ſhows
In you, as Whilome—ſhe knows what ſhe knows.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your Love I will forget; your ſcorn remember
In black revenge, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farewel December.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Hee'l to his Mother now. But tell me, Doris,
What means that Beldame in ſhe knows, ſhe knows:
She's often up with't to the Governeſſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It has relation to ſome uncouth paſſage
Betwixt them, in my Ladies youth I gueſſe,

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Tis ſome ſmock-ſecret I believe. But Gentlemen,
You know how I have laid my ſelf out to you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That, as the Princeſſe ſhall beſtow her ſelf
On eithers Lord; you will embrace his man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And to that you'l hold?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes
This for a Creed, That heaven muſt make its choice and hold you
Of one of them, before ſhe take the other.
You underſtand me; and now ceaſe your ſtrife:
When th'ones Lord's dead, I'le be the others wife.
So farewel Gentlemen. I have ſtaid too long.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: She has given us both a hint now, would we take it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You did not hear me ſay, Kill you his Lord,
Nor you kill his.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: But ſhe has laid a ground
To end a ſtrife, that I ſhould nere ha 'found.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Varillus, come, our Lords may be return'd:
And we be ſhent for loytering.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I muſt think on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now for my Combitants. Th'appointed ground
Is here; the time draws on; and the event
Foreſeen in my imaginary light
Of every paſſe projected in their fight.
In the firſt paſſage, each ſhall wound the other;
Then ſhall they give, lend, pay, change wound for wound,
Till both of them lie fainting on the ground.
Holding between their teeth their doubtful lives:
When I, to end the queſtion, friendly come in,
And with an equal hand diſpatcht'em both.
And ſo into my ambuſh. One approaches.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: This is the place. What is't that urges me
So promptly to deed, which being acted,
Will be th'aſtoniſhment of Heaven and earth?
Applauded no where but in Hell. Fair Tempe,
Let it not be deriv'd to after Ages,
By any uncouth mark upon thy face,
Let not thy graſſy locks, that ſhall receive
The drops of blood, wither and die, condemning
The place that bore them to continual baldneſs;
Let not the impreſs of our labouring feet
Hold it's proportion; nor that part of earth,
Whereon the ſlain ſhall meaſure out his length,
Reſerve the ſtamp, and make it monumental,
By a perpetual ſpring of more procere
And bigger bladed graſs: And, when my ſoul
Hath found an Exit (which my purpoſe is
